												Triggerwarning: (this will be a ranting first impression review)TL:DR version at the bottom.My oh my. Deck13 along with publisher Astragon Entertainment, what is this and did you listen at all to your fanbase?I don't even know where to begin, I clearly remember a dialogue about what the fans wanted for the follow-up and did you collectively decide to do the opposite of what they wanted in about every way imagineable? 2 hours in Im hating everything about this game! Even the good aspects like its music and graphic design which is completely irrelevant in an economic simulator! Why would you focus on that...why? Here's a list of the top of my head:-The impossibility of micromanaging a fleet of ships when one day at normal speed lasts like 7 seconds. Even with pause this game feels like a chore since there's not enough tactical considerations to be made when in port. An AI-captain system would have been nice. Thou, that would automate the only gaming aspect of this release... so yeah... :-(-The attempt at a story...why, its an economic simulation game?!-The non-pause catastrophe. Which ironically is currently somewhat saved by what looks to be a bug (you can pause the game by double-clicking spacebar.) -Developers haven't done anyhing to add in fun gaming elements to break up the monotony. Sending the exact same 3 versions of every ship type around in ports picking up the same-sized identical cargo with little to no variation until the end of time. Or some arbitrary deadline if you play campaign. There's just no decisions to be made in this game of consequence.-Whats with the horrendously random repair costs automatically accepted every time a ship comes in? (ships that currently also detoriate way too fast. Don't think a ship goes from 100% to 33% condition in like 2 months time...)-Are there any pop-up events or gameplay or anything happening ever in this game? Nearly 8 hours in I've not come across anything that wasn't better in the first version in the game. (which was just the "docking and undocking"-minigame when tugboats were on strike) -Why is the AI driving back and forth between just two docks in the first tutorial like tug of war OCD-victim?-The simplicity of the economy simulator. Let me re-iterate: The simplicity of the whole point of a game like this. A sequel should ADD to the complexity, not SUBTRACT from it.Dear Deck13. Did you even playtest this? How about listening to your fanbase the next time around instead of wasting everyones time with this possibly meme-creating epic disaster of a game? I keep seeing you guys mention that people wanted multiplayer in this game. Were you listening to the players actually playing your first game, or the few not in your targetgroup which has no idea how next to impossible it is, making a game like this play in real-time? Your target audience are NOT people who like to frantically click their fingers stiff in some headache-inducing RTS-mode to beat the map before anyone else. They are methodical empire-builders happily spending minutes in port with each ship weighing their alternatives if enough options are given them. Often grinding for hours on end in a relentless "just one more turn"-mode until the early morning birds are chirping away...  And thats just finishing the first three months of play.TL:DRTo anyone considering this game: Do not buy at this point. It's the plague incarnate. (aka modern gaming developers focusing on nothing of relevant importance in their genre games catering to none in their actual audience)Pro:-the UI is functional, mostly because there's no complexityCon:-everything else.edited 11th of may.(completed 2 campaign chapters with silver and gold. I couldn't bring myself to start chapter 3.) P.S: Music is no longer good. I tried it turned on for 4 hours. My ears are now asleep from the monotony of it all.

												TL:DR - This, this is a piece of crap. Do not waste your money.What was presented as a promising and entertaining game/simulation is far from what is expected. Horrible gameplay mechanics are fused with an inadequate UI that together are about as refreshing as Ghandi's flip flop on a hot summer's day. The constant battle against the inexorable timer to get your cargo in before its deadline passes, mixed with an AI that is always far more powerful than the player even on the easiest settings, leads to a feeling of emptiness. I feel all used and neglected after painstakingly investing 11 hours of my life in the hopes that it would get better.I particularly disliked the story. It's a joke. The way the goals are laid out it doesn't really make sense. They somewhat contradict each other. I'm all for something that's a hard challenge, but there's got to be some light at the end of the tunnel. So far it seems the only way to progress through the laughable story is to manually choose every contract, which then leaves you in the ineviable position of not being able to take a holistic approach while you frantically find the next contract before you send the boat on its way. And therefore you end up losing out on neat little Subsidiaries to the AI's 'Mongol Horde' approach.The performance of the software, is poor. It slows down far too quickly and leaves your computer whimpering like it just did ten rounds with Mike Tyson on adderall.Are there any positives? No. Wait! I might, I might just get my money back if I'm lucky.Why is it not possible to see which ports are size limited? I have to take a huge guess and a leap of faith to discover if it's just too big to fit.Why can't the automate cycle actualy do something useful? Why is it unable to be told which speed you would like to set it at... Why can't it keep doing that cycle until I tell it to stop? By the time you get to six ships you just don't have the time to do anything but fill them with contracts. Yes Automator, this is where you step in. 												I was so incredibly hyped for this game, I have watched the development from the day it was first announced, that being said I've struggled with debating if this game is a good, short answer yes long answer: not till they fix a few things. For starters what is new? New vessels such as bulk and tanker vessels, however, they all play the same have very different benefits, The region points system, this system allows you to get benefits from a region by building subsidies and collecting a profit share off of those buildings. There is also now multiplayer which in itself is a mixed bag of nuts, on one hand, I love being able to take on my friends and see who can make the biggest company, however, dont expect to build a shipping empire on multiplayer(ill get into that later). Now what is all the fuss about, well there are a lot of drawbacks from the first game for example in the first game managing a fleet of over 10 vessels was possible (now not as much) the automation system shuts off after running one pattern and doesn't make money so you'll be stuck with notifications that ships need orders. The next system is the sabotaged system which consists of 3 options: bribe subsidies, call in a notification of contraband, freeze bank account. In multiplayer the only real useful one is the contraband call, freezing bank accounts is annoying but does literally nothing to the player other than waste money. Speaking of multiplayer here is where a lot of shortcoming with the game show them multiplayer is great, sorta... the fact that we can to take on other humans makes planning and competing for more fun and more challenging HOWEVER multiplayer is incredibly restricted and I've yet to have a game where I'm able to buy a tier 5 ship by the end of the match, another issue is even while hosting you can't control any of the settings other then sabotage on or off, and game time at 1hr,1.5hr, 2hr this time restriction make 0 sense why cant we play endless or set better goals a good way they could make multiplayer 100x better is by allowing the host to set the goals of the game, by setting the victory conditions such as first company to own X amount of ships, first company to hold X amount of regions, first company to hit X value will win. This would make multiplayer not feel like such a crapshoot another thing would be able to join a game mid game allowing the multiplayer menu not to look like a Gamespy server. The last to MAJOR drawbacks are the UI everything from TO1 that worked so well got completely screwed up the UI is annoying and confusing even for a returning player. The last thing that I have no doubt in my mind will end up changing is the price 25$ is a way to steep for this game currently with all the bugs and drawbacks however if the devs listen to the community and change a lot of the problems it would be worth 25$ easily. However even if the devs don't fix a lot of the drawback the game is still worth picking up on a sale for around 5-10$.TL;DR version PROS:Lots of new contentMultiplayer! No more forced goals multiple game modesthere is now a pause button in single playermost issuses can be fixed through updates easilyCONS:HUGE LACK OF MULTIPLAYER CONTROL (pointless restrictions)Terrible and confusing UINo loansControlling a large fleet is near impossibleyou cant see the cargo loaded on the ships anymorevery high price for what you get

												Oh what to say about this game.Waited eagerly for the sequal to come out after loving the original game yet the developers have dropped the ball.Firstly the single campaign is way to short, and as a player who doesnt like multiplayer games (because of all the griefers and rage quitters that multi player games seem to attract) I find this trend disturbing.But its not only the shortness of the campaign that is the problem, it is the game mechanics. The game is one whole click fest especially when you either get multiple ships or on the later levels. Time passes so quickly when you are looking at contracts you have literally seconds to accept them or bang they are gone. Numerous times have I been furious clicking on missions to a certain port only to find the list has shifted up slightly and I have added cargo to a completely different port (hence losing me money through penalties)On that note lets talk about the way the game handles payments etc, say you haul a load of stuff and its says your bonus is £1.2 million there are certain deuctions that dont make sense especially when you get charged for wear and tear on your ships but for that money they are never repaired.On the note of the ships, seems to me that the sea is made of acid or some kind of corrosive substance as your ships decay at an alarming rating so in some scenarios you are left with a choice of either fixing a rotting ship or buying a new one to increase profits etc.To be fair I was saying to people hold off buying the first game and buy the sequal instead but after playing the campaign mode and not being interested in multiplayer I would have to say the first game is superior to this one. (EA and others take note)There has been a patch to this game and so far it has improved the single player game no end. The addition of the pause function has turned this game from the click fest it was before the patch to a proper strategy business type simulation game. My only major grip still left is the exclusion of a 2560x1080 mode as I have big black lines down the side of my screen and in todays world 2560x1080 is pretty standard.But I do have to give props to the developers for fixing most of what was wrong with the game and it is now enjoyable to play so i revise my rating from negative to positive

												Straight up, Deck13 are good people and they've made a good game.On release day I wrote a pretty negative review of TO2, mainly because it lacked single player pausing. It made the thing, in my mind, basically unplayable. I guess a lot of other people felt the same way, so in the most recent patch, Deck13 added it in. It's super clear all they want is to make a really good game that lots of people enjoy. I'm into that.If you liked TO1, you'll find this to be pretty familiar. Rivals add an interesting challenge and the campaign is a lot more fleshed out. If you played TO1 and though 'I want more story' then this is definitely worth buying. However, they've simplified a couple things in the process - money management doesn't feel as big, and the ship handling minigame is, somehow, even more annoying than last time. If you played TO1 and thought 'I want more intricate mechanics', you might be dissapointed.Regardless, I'm really enjoying TO2 and Im probably going to play the hell out of it when I get the chance. I'm looking forward to multiplayer as well, which is kind of a first for me. Like I said, Deck13 are doing what a lot of other companies don't by actually listening to what players are saying and building their game around what they hear.I've left my old review for posterity below, but it's now totally obsolete.------------------- PREVIOUS REVIEW (MAY 10TH) ---This game has good bones but it's a serious departure from TransOcean 1. Where its predecessor was a careful, intricate, satisfying management sim, TO2 is an uncontrollable mess. I attribute this almost exclusively to the lack of pause in the time controller. I get what they were trying to do, but because time never stops you're just frantically pushing through the game mechanics instead of actually enjoying them. It's supposed to be about selecting the best contracts, planning the most efficient routes, building and managing a fleet, and keeping up with objectives and rivals - but when a day goes by every 10 seconds you can't afford to stop and spend a GD second to think about any of it. It plays like a reactionary mobile game instead of a sim. Not to mention the fact that time continues even when you're docking/undocking or in a port loading screen. The hell is that about.I just feel totally detached from the many great things this game offers. I can only afford two seconds to look at the helpful economic graphs and variety of well-modeled ships. TO1 felt like so much more of a realized world - TO2 might be even better in that regard but I was too busy manically trying to keep up with the game to tell. All I want to do now is sit in silence and have time to think.Also probably 10% of it's still in German.

												“TransOcean 2: Rivals” is developer Deck13’s sequel to their shipping company simulation and economy management game, “TransOcean: The Shipping Company.” The “Rivals” part in the title hints mostly to the multiplayer aspect of the game, but it can also be considered a part of the story.Didn’t think a shipping tycoon game could have a story? Neither did I.The story for this game seems to pick up right where I assume the first game left off, which I haven’t played before. Our avatar is a former shipping magnate who has been reduced to bankruptcy, living life out in the boonies until a lady named Heather Witherspoon approaches us. She introduces herself as the sister of our former advisor, and she wants our help in raising money to pay for her brother’s exorbitant bail. In order to do so, she needs us to helm a shipping company again. With our reluctant agreement, the game’s story mode begins.“TransOcean 2” does a great job in introducing game mechanics to newcomers. Within each chapter is a new mechanic, and by the time we reach the last chapter, we need to use everything we’ve learned in order to succeed. The tutorials are thorough and easy to learn, thanks to their step-by-step examples and hands-on opportunities. Continental regions are introduced gradually in order to give us a feeling of expansion, and to let us get acclimated with the increasing shipping demands. The map, where we will spend the majority of our time, has several viewing options to help us with what we need to do. Those who already know how to play can also opt to skip the tutorial.The only problem with the tutorial is that you are forced to take time out of the chapter to satisfy the requirements. I found myself failing some missions because I lost valuable time and resources trying to follow the directions. Eventually, I just decided to go ahead and do the tutorials before restarting the chapter anew.Considering that the mechanics are integral to your success, the tutorials should not have been designed to be executed at the cost of your mission time. The tutorials should have been a separate instance which closes as soon as you’re done. Imagine if your math teacher started teaching your class the basics of parabola on test day while time is ticking. You’d be hard-pressed to finish the test on time.Once the tutorial is over, you can finally set sail and start conquering the seas. Each chapter has three assigned goals - you only need to fulfill one in order to unlock the next chapter. Fulfilling all three goals per chapter doesn’t really net you any bonus, other than bragging rights and a gold medal.But before you even think of nabbing that gold medal, be prepared to click a lot. This game, which I lovingly called “Carpal Tunnel Click Fest” at one point, pits you against computer players that operate a little too perfectly. They’re not impossible to beat later on in each chapter, but they gain ground against you very quickly in the beginning.This results in a mad dash to your micromanagement zen, this game’s true heart and soul. Each chapter, you are left to micromanage your growing fleet of ships in order to meet the minimum goal. You click through a lot of screens just to load your ships up. Even though you can disable some of the interfaces that pop up, there are still a lot of clicking to do when you’re managing 25 or so ships. You click to buy a ship. You click to pick a contract. You click to take that contract. You click on a destination to sail your ship in order to fulfill that contract. You click to fast-forward time because let’s face it, watching your ship sail slowly is gutwrenchingly boring. You click to check your ship’s gas and maintenance level. You get the idea.---------------------------------------Full review at http://playertheory.com/review/transocean-2-rivals

												Transocean 2 is a game in which you play as a shipping company tycoon. Your goal is to manage your ships and earn millions, avoiding contracts failure. The mechanics are very similar to the first Transocean.Developers added several new features to those already present in the first game: now there are tank and bulk ships, in addition to the container ships on which the first game only focused, there are subsidiaries in all ports, that let you earn extra cash, there is a very useful automation features and, as the battle horse of the game, rival companies that fight with you even with sabotage.The gameplay is focused on fast-paced multiplayer sessions, but there are also singleplayer modes like the endless game and the competition mode against IA rivals.That means that each single match is difficult at the beginning, but once you're on the way, it lets you earn millions with no difficulties. This is good for multiplayer and competition mode because sessions can have a length of a maximum of 2 hours, but is bad for singleplayer endless mode because, after the starting difficulties, it's a 5 lane highway to billions of cash.The game is also a little bit "arcade" in my opinion, in comparison with first Transocean; ships need to be repaired too much for my tastes, refueling costs a lot and sometimes contract value are totally unreasonable, not depending from distances between ports but from "x" factors still I dont' understand. But, I think, this is related to the different structure of the game, if compared whith TO1.On the technical side, the game is very well built, no bugs or crashes after several hours of gameplay. Graphic is very nice.In conclusion, the game is good, it disappointed me a little 'cause I was expecting a worthy successor of Transocean, and Transocean 2 Rivals is not what I expected, but if you like a fast-paced arcade multiplayer focused on shipping companies, this is the game for you.If you like a singleplayer slow-paced more simulative gameplay, so the first Transocean is what fits you best.
